plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: A hardy flowering plant native to North America, known for its bright yellow petals surrounding a dark brown central cone. It thrives in meadows and open woodlands and is often found blooming into early fall.
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans are a symbol of encouragement and motivation, often used in wildflower mixes to bring late-season color.

plants.name: Chrysanthemum morifolium
plants.description: A popular cultivated flower that blooms abundantly in autumn. Garden chrysanthemums come in a variety of vibrant colors and forms, making them a fall garden favorite worldwide.
plants.location: Widely cultivated worldwide, native to East Asia
plants.funFact: Chrysanthemums are the flower of November in the United States and symbolize optimism and joy in many cultures.

plants.name: Grevillea robusta
plants.description: An evergreen tree native to eastern Australia that produces striking orange to golden flowers shaped like spider webs. Flowering peaks in late spring to mid-autumn, providing nectar for birds and bees.
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Silky Oak is not a true oak but is valued for its strong timber and ornamental flowers.

plants.name: Crocosmia aurea
plants.description: A perennial plant native to South Africa, Crocosmia features vibrant, tubular orange to red flowers on arching stems. It blooms during late summer to early autumn in cooler climates but may bloom into October in warmer regions.
plants.location: Southern Africa, cultivated in temperate gardens
plants.funFact: Montbretia attracts hummingbirds and butterflies, making it a favorite for pollinator gardens.
